text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Russian newspapers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
SEVODNYA

- After a brief but dramatic hostage-taking by a Chechen gunmen in the southern region of Dagestan Russians can argue that either the Chechen authorities are unable to control the situation, or that terrorism has become the region's official policy.

- On the day of President's Yeltsin's radio address in which he, praising quality of Russian space technology and vodka, urged Russian to buy domestic products, prices on spirits have gone up in the country.

- The new Russian government has made a few significant steps to improve the economy. It stated its firm position on the results of privatisation, declared a fight against price-forming policy of natural monopolies, and announced the principle of tendering for orders funded by the budget.
- The World Bank will give Russia a two-year $6 billion loan which should help to solve acute social problems.
- The State Statistic Committee has registered growth in the Russian economy in the first three months of 1997.
- Despite President Yeltsin's intentions to abolish the system of commercial banks authorised to deal with the budget money, in reality it would not be possible do away with it.
KOMMERSANT DAILY
- The new government's attack on gas monopoly Gazprom is in fact aiming at weakening the positions of the company's former head, Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin,
- The World Bank will issue a special loan for Russia to restructure natural monopolies.
- The Russian parliament is to decide the future of the stock market.
- The State Duma lower house of the parliament, led by the communist opposition, is to demand a revision in the activity of the State Property Committee activity.
- Russia's Health Ministry is to limit import of foreign medicines in an effort to boost investments in the domestic pharmaceutical industry.
NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA

- Amomg various documents prepared for President Yeltsin's visit to Germany there could be a decree on the 'trophy art' handover, the paper say. Government officials call this information provocative.
- Integration of the former Soviet republics has no firm economic basis.
SOVIETSKAYA ROSSIYA
- Patience is running out in the cash-strapped Russian army and communist ideas are winning sympathy amomg soldiers and officers.
-- Svetlana Kovaleva, Moscow Newsroom, +7095 941 8520
